dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID HELFGOTT wakes with a start in an indistinct place Late thirties, eyelids at half-mast, he stares into the w a flashing red light. David (mumbling) Kissed them all, I kissed them all, always kissed cats, p always did; if a cat’d let me kiss it, I’d kiss it - Cat - always, always, I will - didn’t I? I did because I was was - gotta be different again, haven’t I darl - He realizes the seat beside him is empty and panics. David Where-oh-where, Gillian? Where did she go, where-oh -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His weird begaviour draws attention. Gillian (returning) It’s alright David, I’m right here. David Here - here Gillian, right here. The thing is I thought y She emanates calmness, warmth and is an endless source of instantaneous. DAVID settles … Gillian Where is there to go? David I don’t know darling, I don’t know, I’m hopeless without Gillian You’ve got your contacts in, silly. david  I’m a silly, it’s true, it’s true. A braying laugh. Whooahh! Gillian Shhhh. David Oooh, shhh - shhh, sorry darling, sorry - Gillian It’s alright. Stretch your legs. David Do you think so? Perhaps I should, perhaps I should stret stretch my legs? He stands. Gillian Good idea. David Good idea, that’s right - AIRPORT ANNOUNCEMENT : Flight 313 to London via Frankfurt 15 minutes - David  Whooahhh, London, Gillian, London! Gillian Yes … Shhh. David Shhh … He looks out the rain-spattered window at the flashing re aircraft being fuelled immediately outside the window. David Shhh, softly, softly, new story … Dissolve to iridescent neon raindrops coursing down a win somewhere, Suddenly a desperate face fills the frams. It’ twenties. The full head of hair, falling around his soaki this is years earlier; a sodden cigarette hangs from his off the end of his nose. He’s looking into ...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MOBY'S WINEBAR
dialogues.text: A pianist croons the last few bars of ‘Only the Lonely’. the last two patrons to the door. TONY and a woman in her put up chairs; the PIANIST, SAM, slips into a stool at th all we hear is DAVID’s anxious breathing as we are seeing He raps on the window. sylvia What does he want? Sam A drink probably. Get lost! DAVID disappears from the window and appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Poor thing. Let him in. Tony He’s a derro’! sylvia He’s saturated. Resume DAVID’s POV as more words are exchanged then TONY the door to him. tony What’s the problem, mate? david (a hundred miles an hour) Sorry, sorry, sorry, mate, I’m the problem, I think I’m t problem. And wet! But it’s not an ideal world. Is it an i have to make the most of it, I mean, this is the way we f yeah-yeah-yeah! But it’s more ideal than it was, I mean, privileged, we’re privileged, we’re priviliged, aren’t we people would be burned to a steak wouldn’t they, er … He sees ‘MOBY’S’ embroidered on TONY’s tunic. Dvid Moby, yay Moby, pleased to meet you - Tony Tony. Who are you? David (hugs Tony) Tony, Tony not Moby Tony. Who am I Tony? Who knows Tony? Whooahh! David, I’m David, I’m David Tony … How does that sylvia Hello David. How can Sylvia help? David Sylvia? Is it Sylvia? How are you Sylvia? Good to see you He throws an arm around her neck as though greeting a lon david Sylvia Tony, Tony Sylvia. Sylvia What can we do for you, David? David Do for me, Sylvia, what, yes, got to stop talking, got to it’s a problem isn’t it? Is it a problem? sylvia It’s alright David; just tell Sylvia why you’re here. David Ahhhh! Well it’s a mystery, a mystery, a mystery - Sylvia Are you lost? David Am I lost? Perhaps that’s it. I’m lost, I’m lost, I’m los He sees the piano. David Ooh you have a piano. Is that your piano, Sylvia? Beautif Sylvia beautiful Tony? You too Tony. Perhaps I could play You say, you say. Sam Like hell baby. Sylvia Shut up, Sam. David (lurches towards SAM) Hell baby, the Devil, Diablerie Sam baby!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Get outta here. TONY is in fits of laughter … sylvia David - David Sylvia, such a beaitiful piano exquisite Sylvia, Sylvia-T He moves towards it. David Could I play, you say, you say? Sylvia Why don’t you tell Sylvia where you live? David Live, Sylvia, ligve - live and let live - that’s very imp molto. But then again it’s a lifelong struggle, isn’t it to survive, to survive undamaged and not destroy any livi The point is, if you do something wrong you can be punish life so I think it’s a lifelong struggle; is it a lifelon you do it’s a struggle, a struggle to keep you head above chopped off. I’m not disappointing you am I Sylvia-Tony-M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYLVIA’s old Humber belts past in the heavy rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY is driving. SYLVIA is in front, both laughing along David (a braying laugh) ‘Helfott’ - ‘with the help of God’ - that’s what it means You see, Daddy’s daddy was religious, vee-eery religious, of a meanie. But he got eterminated, didn’t he, so God di Whooahhh. Not very funny is it, Sylvia? Very sad, really aren’t I, such a meanie because I haven’t got a soul, is right isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Daddy, daddy said so. No such thing as a soul. A train whiste sounds in the distance. Sylvia That’s ridiculous David  Ridiculous; you’re right. I’m ridiculous Sylvia-Tony, and because it was a tragedy, a tragedy … The car drives into a tunnel. Blackness in the tunnel. David - (V.0.) … a ridiculous tragedy. The sound of the train wheels rattling, blasting a signal light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if in a dream, children’s faces turn to look at camera slow-motion. Some are made up, prissy, perfectly dressed accompanies by ‘stage mothers’, fanning themselves in the eyes focused on the next contestant as he makes his way u POV. Over this we fade up.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Let’s hear it for our next young contestant, David Helfgo DAVID, nine, makes his way down the aisle clutching a sco meticulously parted and he wears spectacles. A little unc looks back to his father. PETER HELFGOTT is a thickset Po fifties. He motions for DAVID to keep going, then sits, a DAVID walks up some steps onto the stage. Announcer David’s going to play the piano for us, aren’t you David? David Yes. He’s stage-struck by all those faces looking at him, incl two elderly females and a man in his thirties. His name i Announcer What are you going to play? DAVID’s attention is taken by a fan nearby, blades whirri

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: David, what are you going to play? DAVID snaps out of it, when from the audience …

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (stands) Chopin! The Polonaise! PETER smiles full of charm, and a little embarrassed at a applauds encouragingly then sits. DAVID’s hells click on the bare boards as he crosses to t centre-stage. HE adjusts his music. His bony legs barely difgets, looks into the spotlight. He takes a deep breath Chopin’s Polonaise in A Flat, the first few bars ring out surprising everyone - BEN ROSEN in particular. DAVID attacks the keys with such gusto that the piano inc his foot around the leg of the stool and drit in. He play again. He blurs some notes. Again he readjusts the stool pages of his score flutter to the ground but DAVID plays end. ROSEN watches the courageous performance with wry am backstage flustered. To the ANNOUNCER :

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The piano, it is disgraceful. The piano slews forward. DAVID stands and plays the final intensity.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: This kid’s good; he’s great. A moment. Peter He’s my son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expectant faces of two young girls loom large as they from their perch in a tree - MARGARET, 12, and SUZIE, 5. Suzie Did he win or lose? Along the street, DAVID walks a few paces behind PETER. Margaret He lost. DAVID jumps over the cracks in the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Now we’ll all cop it. Damn you David Helfgott. INT. HELfgOTT HOUSE - DAY PETER broods, his mind turning over. A scratch recording Piano Concerto plays on the gramophone. DAVID moves a che PETER. RACHEL HELFGOTT, PETER’s wife, lights the woodstove. Her is now blanketed by the gollow look of years of submissio homeowrk on the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: IT’s your turn, Daddy. PETER flicks a look at the board a moves a piece.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You know, David, when I was your age, I bought a violin, violin, it was a beautiful violin. All listen to the stor Do you know what happened to it? DAVID glances at a photo of a stern rabbi high up on the

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He smashed it. A moment, the PETER slams his fist on the small table, kn pieces off.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You are a lucky boy. MY father never let me have music.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know, Daddy. Peter You are very lucky. David Yes Daddy. (lights up.) Will I play for you? Peter No. You pick up these pieces. DAVID proceeds to on hands and knees while PETER goes to off.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (to DAVID) I bet I could’ve won.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (in Yiddish) Quiet. DAVID pokes a face at MARGARET. She does the same to him, to see. DAVID gallops the knight across the board. There’ door. MARGARET makes to go.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Margaret! She stops.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I told you, tell your friends not to come. She sits. There’s another knock which PETER ignores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN ROSEN walks around the sideway of the dilapidated old there's anyone home. He spots someone in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Hello. It's SUZIE.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Hello. Rosen Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. HELFOYY HOUSE. BACKYARD
dialogues.text: PETER looks across.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Daddy, there's someone here. ROSEN appears at the back door.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: I hope I'm not interupting … PETER stands in the doorway looking down at him, resentin

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Ben Rosen. I was one of the judges. PETER doesn't accept the proffered handshae. He motions S

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (to ROSEN) Yes? Rosen You left before all the prizes were announced. DAVID appears behind PETER.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: You were very good this afternoon, David. David Thank you. Peter He can play better. Rosen Maybe he was a little too good. Some people don't like th special prize for his courage. PETER takes the envelope from ROSEN and peels it open. MA the piano in the background.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: It was a very difficult piece you chose, David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Daddy chose it. ROSEN notices RACHEL sneak a look out the window at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Even great pianists think twice before tackling the Polon DAVID's eyes light up as PETER takes a pound note from th

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A prize for losing! He pockets the money.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: I wouldn't call him a loser.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (in Yiddish, to MARGARET) Stop, that is enough! She stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: (in Yiddish) She plays well too. The Yiddish catches PETER out.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (disdainful) They all play. Rosen I'm quite sure David could win lots of competitions with He offers a business card showing his qualifications.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I teach him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: You've obviously done well.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes - and no one taught me; no music teachers Mr. Rosen.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Of course, it's just that a few bad habits can sometimes between winning or losing. He knows which strings to pull. If you'd like to think about it. He hands PETER the card. PETER holds his look and closes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is in darkness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bedroom PETER wakes to the sound of the piano filt living area. He walks down the hallway, drawn by the sparse, haunting familiar: Rachmaninov's Third Piano Concerto. Entering th DAVID playing the piano in near darkness. DAVID struggles fingers across the keys, faltering to a stop … Peter Rachmaninov? David It's beautiful. PETER sits beside his son.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You taught yourself? David From the record. Peter The record?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You always play it. PETER smiles. Peter It is very difficult, the hardest piece in the world, Dav David Will you teach me? Pause. PETER deflects.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: One day you will play it, you will make me very proud. PETER hugs his small son.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Next time, what are we going to do? David WE're going to win.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We're going to win! (Kisses him.) Now go to bed. David Goodnight, Daddy. Moments later PETER takes a score from a battered suitcas Rachmaninov's Third Piano Concerto. IT's awesome in its c page. PETER positions it on the piano, then contemplates thickset, clumsy hands. The framed photo of the rabbi loo clenches his fists in frusturation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID and PETER walk along a cobbled path. DAVID stops to in a large pond. PETER bustles him along to the frontdoor threatens. PETER rings the bell. DAVID smiles and goes to stops him with a look. The door is opened by ROSEN.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I have decided I would like you to teach David. (Hands him some music.) This!

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Rachmaninov? Don't be ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He can play it already.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: He's just a boy. How can he express that sort of passion?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You are a passionate man, Mr. Rosen. You will teach him,

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: No. I'll teach him what I think is best. DAVID is entranced by some chimes hanging over his head.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Rachmaninov is best. (No response.) But you are his teacher; I let you decide.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: (dry) Thank you. We'll start with Mozart. He lets DAVID in and PETER goes to follow but the door is him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can't afford to pay. The door shuts, leaving PETER stranded. It starts to rain issues from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID plays the scales. ROSEN spots PETER at the side win shuts the blind on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER, in the raid,presses his ear to the window. The sou from:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy rain. Sylvia's car pulls up. She jumps out and open

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Come on David, Sylvia's getting wet. She drags him out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wet Sylvia, sorry Sylvia, such a wet. They run past a sign clanging on a chain: 'Eden Lodge'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYLVIA is appalled by what she sees. The room is littered rubbish, cigarette butts.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Is this your room, David? David It's a room, it's a room, home sweet home. She looks at the piano - a battered honky-tonk, chipped k cigarettes. Sylvia You can play?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Kind of, kind of play kind of sweet kind Sylvia. (Picks up sheet music.) Chopin, Sylvia, Chopinzee! The Pole-popolski. Like Daddy they were concentrated. He brushes a Rachmaninov score aside.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Golly, I don't know. Aeons I think, a few years, a few. A wrong with Schubert except syphilis, was it syphilis? I t got typhoid on top of it and that was the end of him wasn Shenotices a row of tablet bottles by the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That was a bit careless wasn't it Sylvia - Whooah we lost didn't live to swim another day. MINOGUE enters; late fifties, he has a thick Scottish acc look in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Him. I was a naughty boy wasn't I? Was I a naughty boy? C head.

dialogues.speaker: MINOGUE
dialogues.text: I was about to send out a search party.He shuts the windo

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whooahhh, a search party Jim, a party! I won't be invited

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: He showed up at my restaurant, seemed a bit lost.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How's that Sylvia, how's that? A party! A celebration. A

dialogues.speaker: MINOGUE
dialogues.text: He's good at that. Thank you for bringing him back. He ushers her out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Time for a wine and a very fine time. A mardi gras and a Whoooah Jim Jim Jim, a party. He realizes he's on his own. He stares blankly at the rai getting louder until it becomes the sound of applause, fr

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONCERT HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: Rows of enthusiastic clapping hands.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER
dialogues.text: The winner and State champion, David Helfgott. As the wild applause continues, we end on a big close-up from a bow, now a young adolescent. Several years have pa

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: He won! David won!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I can hear that. I'm not deaf. RACHEL nurses baby LOUISE.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That's your clever brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER bursts through the door, rushes up to ROSEN and kis

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We won. We won.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Thjanks to Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Now he can play Rachmaninov. ROSEN sighs. DAVID takes centre stage. PETER watches from and the other contestants.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER
dialogues.text: And now to present David with the prize money, out very s America, ladies and gentlemen, currently on tour in Austr STERN shakes hands with DAVID. PETER applauds vigorously, excitement.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He's my son!

dialogues.speaker: STERN
dialogues.text: (to DAVID) You have a very special talent, DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you Mr. Stern. So do you. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: STERN
dialogues.text: How much are you prepared to give to your music, David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (from the wings) Everything. ROSEN settles PETER.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Everything. But I do like tennis - and chemistry too. Laughter. PETER laughs too.

dialogues.speaker: STERN
dialogues.text: Do you play tennis as well as you play Mozart?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Only against the wall at home, I bounce the ball against

dialogues.speaker: STERN
dialogues.text: How would you like to come to a special school in the Sta off the walls? DAVID's imagination is captured.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: America?

dialogues.speaker: STERN
dialogues.text: Land of the Free. Home of the Vrave! You know? PETER's expression falters.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, what an honour for our young state to study in America. The audience applauds. People congratulate PETER.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: That's fantastic, Peter. PETER applauds enthusiastically despite the uncomfortable fully understand. DAVID beams into the audience, soaking feeling. Fade to white: SUZIE'S VOICE: 'And now, all the way from America, David

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID steps out form behind the bright white sheets hangi repeatedly to an imaginary audience.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: He's not from America. She takes the washing off the line. The yard is crammed w scrap metal.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: He's going to America and when he comes back he'll be com you David? DAVID bows still, until MARGARET unpegs the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to miss him?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. DAVID smiles as he realizes she means it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Me too. Youth's voice Margaret. MARGARET puts the washing down and exits the back gate.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I have no money to send David to America.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: We'll raise it. PETER scoffs. RACHEL looks over from the sink where she's bones into a pot.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Bar mitzvah.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: David hasn't had his bar mitzvah. PETER looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Religion is nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: It's also a goldmine if you know where to dig.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: One day I'll play with an orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Can I come when you do?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You can ride with me in my cadillac. SUzIE Where are you going to live in America? Behind them, PETER steps out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: With a nice Jewish family they said.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And this is not a nice family?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh yes, very nice, very -

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You are very lucky to have a family! He stabs a look at the abandoned laundry baskey - no sign

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER's face appars over the rear corrugated iron fence w barbed wire running across the top. In the laneway MARGAR GANGLY YOUTH. Seeing PETER she pales.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I have to go. She hurries to the gate. When she opens it, PETER is ther him, his eyes burning through her.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: It's one of the finest music schools in the world.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It is for his father to decide. Rosen David will be well looked after, I assure you. RACHEL nods politely, unconvinced. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: (Perplexed, steps closer) Rachel, David could well be one of the truly great pianis

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: He is just a boy, Mr. Rosen. He still wets the bed. ROSEN absorbs this. MARGARET fumes past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rickety pram wheel wobbles along. Widen to reveal PETER dilapidated old pram down the ordinary suburban street, f SUZIE wearing grubby school uniforms. Several kids playing hopscotch stop as they see them appr path for the odd trio to pass. SUZIE looks down her nose the hopscotch without missing a beat as the trio continue watch after them, like they were from another planet. Wide shot. DAVID and SUZIE collect several bottles which sidewalk, put them in the pram and walk on with PETER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER straddles a large piece of scrap metal - the head o heaves it off the pram with a great sense of satisfaction metal and a stack of empty bottles in the corner of the y

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You see how fit I am, you see how strong?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Show me Daddy, show me where the lion scratched you when circus. PETER extends his hand with a sense of theatricality to r scar.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That's what happens when you get too close to the bars. He stands in a body-builder pose, barrel-chested.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Come on David, hit me. Suzie Me!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: David, as hard as you can.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay. Here comes. Ready. DAVID's punch bounces off PETER's stomach.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: My turn Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Harder. Come on! (DAVID punches again.) You see. A man of steel.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Steel alright. (Rubbing his fist.)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No one can hurt me! Because in this world only the fit su RACHEL watches from the laundry, sweating over the hot co side to the fun and games.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The weak get crushed like insects. Believe me, if you wan you have to be fit and strong, like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elderly receptionist types with one finger on an antiq sits in the narrow corridor, arms folded tightly. He woul else. On the wall opposite him a long line of faces - the rabbis of the synagogue stare down. PETER glances at the folded newspaper on the seat next to the front page - a photo of DAVID seated at the piano wit pointing at a score as if taking DAVID through a lesson. The elderly typist removes the sheet from the typewriter nods politely, then resumes his steely composure. The doo opens. PETER stands.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: (exits the office with David) See you next week David, and don't forget to study. (He hands him the 'soncino chumash'.) We'll see you in Schul, Elias. PETER feigns a polite smile.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you Rabbi. They walk off. DAVID takes The Maccabean from him, noting copies of this latest issue. PETER puts his arm on DAVID' in, as if protecting him from an invisible foe. The RABBI goes back into his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POSTMAN rides along the street, past DAVID waiting ex gate. No mail today. DAVID watches after him, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chandelier glistens above the entry. DAVID and PETER en foyer is dripping with dignity and provincial social elit immediately set on by the hostess, MRS. BOKSER, a busy so

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BOKSER
dialogues.text: Mr. Helfott, it's exciting isn't it? David, the Lord Mayo She takes DAVID by the hand, dragging him away. A WAITER from a try but PETER's attention is on DAVID being whiske Cut to a short while later. Faces glowing with appreciati jewellery surround DAVID. MRS. Bokser And I would like to thank our wonderful Lord Mayor for es for David to go to America. (Applause.) And now to play for us, our very own David Helfgott. ROSEN notes PETER's embittered look around the room as th DAVID with affection on his way to the piano - a shake of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER's voice can be heard raging inside. PETER - (V.o) These people are a disgrace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUZIE nestles up to MARGARET and baby LOUISE, frightened

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A disgrace. (A loud thump.) They think they are so important. (Curses in Yiddish.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter paces, like a caged lion, bursting with anger. Peter What do they know with their furs and their diamonds? It stomach. RACHEL is on the receiving end.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And Rosen. Pah!

dialogues.speaker: INT. DAVID'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: DAVID lies in bed listening.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What kind of man is he? He has no children. He's not marr to me about Rosen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER curses again in Yiddish. Rachel He only wants for David the same as you have always wante

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Don't ever compare me to him. What has he suffered? Not a does he know about families? Do you forget how your siste He thumps the wall by he photograph o RACHEL and her sist

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And my mother and father. (Yiddish.) Stupid woman. Stupid! Cut to later. PETER sits in near darkness, just staring i is looking at a scrapbook, articles and photos of DAVID t stunning career, including a photo with Isaac Stern. PETER stares, his mind turning the same thing over and ov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID is asleep. A shadow falls across him. It's PETER. H there, burdened, watching over his sleeping son. He kisse forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID bows to warm applause.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Thank you Comrade Helfgott; your son is a credit to you. PETER proudly puts his hand on DAVID's shoulder. On the w flag and a Stalin portrait. The gathering consists of 25 people, members of the socie mid-seventies, warmly applauds her appreciation of DAVID' Cut to later. Cocktails are being served. PETER is involv looks around for DAVID. No sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID takes a book from the shelf - it's on Russia. A GIR him through the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You play beautifully.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: My name is Sonia.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm David.

dialogues.speaker: SONIA
dialogues.text: I know who you are. She laughs; so does DAVID. He's quite taken.

dialogues.speaker: SONIA
dialogues.text: You have the most wonderful hands. He looks at his hands, like he'd never noticed. Then look

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So do you. She smiles warmly.

dialogues.speaker: SONIA
dialogues.text: You're going to America? David That's right. Sonia Perhaps one day you will go to Russia too. DAVId Yes. Why not? PETER - (O/s) David. DAVID puts his hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Right here. PETER gives SONIA a charming smile.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Excuse us. Ther eis someone important who wants to meet y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We recognize the woman from above - KATHERINE SUSANNAH PR reflects a sharp intelligence and strong humanity. Katherine I've never met anyone who plays the piano as beautifully

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And I've never met a writer before, Mrs. Prichard.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: You must be very proud of him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: As proud as a father can be. KATHERINE smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: I have a long-suffering old piano at home.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A suffering piano? Katherine From neglect. Perhaps you'd come and play it for me, Davi PETER goes to speak, but DAVID interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh yes, anything to help. klatherine I'd like that very much. david Me too.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Your attention Comrades. I wish to propose a toast to our Katherine That's my cue. Excuse me. SECRETARy - and very special guest this evening, Katherine Susannah PETER applauds along with everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You will learn much from this old woman, David. She has b As KATHERINE joins the SECRETARY up front, she smiles at

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (Nudges DAVID) Smile. Look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID hurries out the front door excitedy at the sound of The POSTMAN finds a letter for DAVID in his satchel and h playfully dropping it into the letter box. DAVID grabs it it's come from.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: America! INT. HELFgOTT HOUSE - NIGHT David excitedly reads a letter from 'The Michleburg famil

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: '…we have been informed of your exceptional talent and ca privileged we feel to have you come and stay with us'. PETER listens as he chops vegetables on a board, alongsid

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: 'You will be pleased to know that we are having the Bosen for you.' PETER scoops the vegetables into a steaming pot.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: 'We eagerly await your innement -'

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Imminent, fool.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I wonder if they've got a cadillac?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: 'Imminent arrival… And look forward to hearing you play f Simon and Basha Mickleburg.' PETER chops more vegetables - the simple words are like d mindful of his brooding silence.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Read it again.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Not again! She turns the radio up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You're just jealous. PETER simmers…

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Just the bit about the parakeet and the dog and the two c MARGARET puts her hands over her ears.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: '… you'll enjoy the company of our parakeet and our poodl MArgaret Pig! It is not! She grabs the letter and DAVID tries to get it; all yelli off' around the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jealous, jealous, give it! Margaret Pig! Pig!

dialogues.speaker: ENOUGH
dialogues.text: He sweeps a bottle of milk off the bench; it explods at S

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Enough of this nonsense! DAVID pales as PETER tears the letter up. SUZIE cries.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Forget it! You are not going. David is not going anywhere (Silence.) What are you looking at, you fools? He is not going to Am anyone destroy this family! David Daddy, but Daddy please -

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know what is best, David. I know because I am your fath family. Stunned silence. DAVID runs out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: David! David come back - The door slams.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (in Yiddish)Why now!? Why!? PETER slaps her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is in darkness. DAVID knocks. He's been running

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mr. Rosen? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mr. Rosen. It's David. (He bangs at the door.) Please Mr. Rosen. Please… There's nobody home. DAVID slides down the door, clutchin bewildered. Cut to water rippling in the moonlight. DAVID's reflectio He watches the distortion of his face in the water, then after a moment the image settles again. He puts his head shoulders. Cut to underwater, DAVID's face, as bubbles escape from h are :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We realize DAVID's face is underwater in the bath. He sur just stares, breathing awkwardly. PETER enters in a dressing gown. PEter Come on David, you have been long enough. Are you feeling all this nonsense. This is your home, this is where you b DAVID's POV: PETER peeling off his dressing gown singlet, no sound - it's like a dream. PETER goes to get in but st something in the bath that horrifies him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: David! (He slaps David's head.) You animal. You disgusting animal. He slashes at DAVID with a white singlet, splashing water

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: To shit in the bath. To do this to me. You callous boy. T DAVID barely reacts as the attack with the wet singlet co bare back, his head… water arcs across the small bathroom Just as suddenly as it started, it's over. PETER is gone. walls like blood. A drop forms on the flickering light gl just stares… in shock. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL is huddled with SUZIE, MARGARET and LOUISE in the Jewish community watches as DAVID sings from the Torah, t head bowed, almost cowering. ROSEN senses something is wrong. He looks across at PETER expression gives nothing away. Close-up: PETER, a man of steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide shot. The house is in near darkness. ROSEN walks up scrapes the front gate open. He knocks at the door. No an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hallway - ROSEN's silhouette through the opawue gl Reveal PETER, in the shadowy darkness, the outside world

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is thick with tension. RACHEL amuses little LOUIS the scrapbook. MARGARET fingers the same note on the pian knocking echoes again through the solemn quiet, like a kn

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: This house is like a concentration camp. She lets the piano lid drop shut. In the hallway ROSEN's door.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Peter? I know you can hear me. Don't do this to David. Yo PETER's eyes glow with anger in the darkness. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Peter! ROSEN give up, turns to go, but then as an afterthought:

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, don't inflict bloddy Rachmaninov on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hallway - ROSEN's shadow disappears. The gate is h he leaves. PETER just stands there. The sound ofROSEN's car is heard headlights flicker across PETER's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER stands over the bed where DAVID lies, facing away.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: David… (No reply.) David. My boy? Still you don't speak to me? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's a terrible thing to hate, to hate your fatehr. Silence. He sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Life is cruel, but music, it will always be your friend. let you down in the end. Everything. Believe me. (Pause.) Please don't hate me David. He begins to cry. He sobs… DAVID looks at his father crying, full of confusion. Thei pulls DAVID up and hugs him. DAVID throws his arms around

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (in Yiddish) Don't hate me. PETER kisses DAVID repeatedly on the side of the face, al

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's tough, life can be tough but you have to survive, sa

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Survive, Daddy… Peter That's right, David. No one will love you like me. You ca will always be there… always be with you, forever. Do you David Yes, Daddy, forever… They hug as we begin to pull back… looking down on them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Forever and ever…

dialogues.speaker: PETER AND DAVID
dialogues.text: Forever and ever…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ADULT DAVID sits on the floor in the middle of the room, amidst the mess of paper and music spread around him. He It's a crumpled old letter with distinctive letterhead: R DAVID peers myopically at it - we only glimpse a few word we are pleased to inform you…' Fade up - music, from the past - 'Sospiro' by Liszt. It c INT. TRAIN TUNNEL. DAY. THE PAST. The train exits a tunnel into bright strobing light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright light pours through a jungle of trees and exotic p way down the long overgrown drive. Finally, a small weath into view, its verandah wreathed in wisteria, jasmine and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photograph of DAVID is removed from a paper bag. It's D supremely confident.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Perfect; I'll treasure it until the day I die. DAVID has finished eating dinner.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Are you full?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Full as a goog, Katherine; full as a goog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David plays the final bars of the Appassionata. When he f KATHERINE in front of several photos on the mantel, lost his palying.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Each time you play 'Sospiro' it expresses so completely…

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that good?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: (sits next to him) It's divine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Inexpressibly divine. Katherine Quite! He starts playing again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Tell me a story, Katherine. What story is it today? DAVID watches her - eyes closed, head swaying.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: A new story - drops of water.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Raindrops? KaTHERINE Yes, raindrops. DAVID's head sways as he plays the passage.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Listen. It's the wind. Cut to the verandah. Moonlight filters through.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The wind! Leaves flutter across the ground… Branches sway…

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The stream… Katherine - (V.O.) The river…

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The ocean, Katherine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photograph of DAVID, now framed, is on the mantel. KATHERINE's VOICE … You are Krishna, Christ and Dionysus. In your beauty, t … The camera moves towards the piano, where DAVID is stoope top of his head until he lokos up and, we realize, years DAVID is now a young adult. He scribbles the words of the awed by their beauty as she continues to read.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: 'To you, all these wild weeds and wind flowers of my life lay them at your feet.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide shot. Lights burn warmly in the windows of the old h

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: the front door opens and KATHERINE sees DAVID out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good night, Katherine. She kisses him warmly. He ambles off, awkward as a puppy, Katherine Good luck, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stagehands carefully position the grand piano onstage. Li being set for a performance. Cut to backstage, hands soak water, next to it is a score of Rachmaninov's Third. DAVI the water, the poise and confidence of his younger years shambling insecurity. He throws a nervous look around at A CELLIST warms up, a VIOLINIST paces, a CONTESTANT goes another pianist, ROGER, 25, warms up on an old upright pi Cut to the foyer. The audience assembles, waiting to go i the occasion is the 'ABC - NATIONAL CONCERTO COMPETITION' Arriving amidst the furs and jewellery, PETER is just ano Something draws his attention: BEN ROSEN on the stair. He Neither hids their contempt. ROSEN comments to his compan

dialogues.speaker: ROSEN
dialogues.text: Poor man's Leopold Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Onstage. A piano cover is removed revealing gold letters is drawn towards the grand piano, mesmerized by its magni oblivious to everything else. The sound of applause fades

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: That was out final contestant -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNOUNCER - (radio v.0., continued) …David Helfgott, who gave a stirring performof Rachmanino Piano in D Minor… KATHERINE looks at the framed photo of adolescent DAVID

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Bravo, David. ANNOUNCER - (radio v.o.) (radio V.O.) The judges will now confer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the audience, PETER is anxious as the jury confers. RO Backstage, THE CONTESTANTS assemble in readiness, wishing An evnelope is handed to the ANNOUNCER who adjusts his bo the stage. DAVID shuffles nervously on the spot, standing focus is on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It's a tough game isn't it, Roger?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: A bloodsport. announcer Ladies and gentlemen. PETER leans forward in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: I am pleased to announce the winner of this year's ABC Na Competition is - Roger Woodward. Applause. PETER's face turns to stone. DAVId Well done, well done, Roger. The other contestants congratulate ROGER then he walks ou loud ovation. DAVID watches from the wings as ROGER takes his bows in t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A framed photo of KATHERINE's father is on the mantel, am the one of DAVID as a bright adolescent.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What was he like, Katherine? She looks up from her book. david Your father. She puts the book aside.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: He was forever busy in his study. 'Go away, Kattie, I'm w say. One day, I was very young, I got so annoyed I emptie his desk and I scrawled on his work, pages of it. When he seething with anger; I could feel it. David fills with dread. katherine 'What are you doing?' he shouted. It startles DAVID, feeding his own fears.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: There was this terrible silence. I just stared at him and I'm writing.' David is suspended.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: He ran at me and picked me up, and cuddled me breathless. effort he always called it. Silence. KATHERINE sees there's something troubling DAVID

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: What is it? (No reply.) David? He extracts a letter from his pocket. She takes it and re

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: The Royal College of Music. A scholarship. David that's m

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Won't cuddle me Katherine, oh no. He wrings his hands full of anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: He can't stop you, David. David Such an angry lion. Katherine Nonsense, he's a pussycat. She holds him comfortingly and looks into his uncertain e strength.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: I'll miss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up - a small box which KATHERINE takes from the sid

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: These were for my son but he left home before I could giv DAVID opens it and takes out an exquisite pair of red fur

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: You'll need them. It gets very, very cold in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fiery red sky. DAVID walks along, churning with anxiety the gloves out of the gladstone bag he's carrying. He dra off leaving the bag behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID enters quietly, makes his way through the darkness. PETER's VOICE Where have you been? A table lam is switched on to reveal PETER sitting there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I missed the train. PETER's eyes glow with hostility.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That Prichard woman! DAVID goes to move away.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What is this? The gloves DAVID's wearing. He takes a backward step.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What? (Stands.) Look at me. Look at me! DAVID has no choice. PETER's eyes burn through him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: David? DAVID slowly extracts the letter, backs away as PETER rea

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You think you can just do as you please? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I… I want to go; I'm going. You can't stop me. A terrible silence. Then PETER comes at DAVID like a lumb

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I am your father. Your father! Who has done everything fo callous boy! DAVID tries uselessly to fend him off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Daddy -

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I am your father! He slaps DAVID around the head, kocking his glasses off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Please Daddy -

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Stupid boy! SUZIE runs in and tries to pull PETER away.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: No - PETER gives SUZIE a backhand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It's not Suzie's fault. DAVID charges forward, crashing PETER into the wall.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (racing in) Stop it! Stop it! PETER throws DAVID across the room. MARGARET intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Get out of the way! He picks up a chair and throws it against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (screams) No! Dogs bark. Neighbours' lights go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go? Go! Go on! He has DAVID in a headlock, choking him. They bang into t together in a fierce struggle. The photo of the rabbi cra Furniture is skittled - chess pieces scattered. Rachel (screams, in Yiddish) No! Stop! Stop! She bashes his arms with her fists trying to get him to l can't breathe. MARGARET tries to pull PETER away.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I'll get the police! Finally, PETER lets go of DAVID who slumps to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He's alright, leave him. Catching his breath, he sees his terrified family, only n horror of what has happened. Silence. DAVID fumbles for his glasses. He picks up the c

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: David, are you alright? Are you? PETER approaches, with remorse.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Come on, David. David I'm old enough to make up my own mind. He backs away, into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (laughs) He thinks he's going to London.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I've been accepted by the Royal College of Music. DAVID is full of confusion.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What do you think is going to happen to you in London? DAVID wipes his bloody nose, edges down the corridor. Peter David, listen to me. If you go, you will never be anybody lose a brother. Is that what you want? You want to destro david I'm sorry, sorry - He opens the door. RACHEL holds the girls, all crying. Peter If you love me you will stop this nonsense; you will not Don't make me do it! david …Sorry… peter David! DAVID steps over the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You will be punished for the rest of your life!!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The door slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID runs, in a sweat, on the road to KATHERINE's. The h straight down on him. It blasts its horn as it swerves ar Cut to a blazing fire in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music scores burn, school books, David's clothes… PETER t stokes the flames. Burning in the fire is the scrapbook - images of YOUNG DA flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Royal College of Music' - gold letters carved in sto ADULT DAVID looks up: we are back in the present. He abso building as he shuffles up the steps. Behind him, the mag Albert Hall. On the curb, GILLIAN is getting out of a taxi. When she l sign of DAVID. INT. RCOM CORRIDOR. DAY - The present DAVID shuffles along, past the practice rooms from where sound, merging into one another as DAVID continues on his of childish wonder. He hears something distinct… a piano. a practice room at the enf of the corridor. He peers thro panel, into: INT. PRACTICE ROOM. DAY - the present There's a female student practicing with her teacher. She the door a moment before it ducks out of sight. DAVID sneaks another impish look in… the quickly retreats slides into frame and retreats. As if by magic, when the face appears again, it's no long YOUNGER DAVID, longer hair falling in ringlets around his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are back in the past and there's an elderly teacher in looks at his watch impatiently to make a point.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Bravo, David. Now remind me why I'm here. DAVId (enters) Sorry, Mr. Parkes, sorry. PROFESSOR CECIL PARKES is in his sixties. His left arm ha crippled by a stroke.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: It's fortunate I'm a deeply forgiving human being. DAVID's VOICE Liszt was like that, wasn't he, a great humanitarian - no knew him personallor anything but he had a respect for ev creature; so that was nice of him, wasn't it? Or so I rea (Plonks a book down.) Very improvisatorial, very sensual, Mr. Parkes. Virtuosic

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Bacchanalian! Boldness of attack! He bashes out chords with his one good arm.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Diablerie! The Devil, David!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whooaah, mustn't break the piano.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Liszt broke plenty!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Right! Swept up, DAVID bashes out some chords - PARKES stops him

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: (quietly) But you must play what's on the page; you're not Liszt, r

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Not even slightly Mozart. PARKES plays (with his good hand) to demonstrate.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Come on, fill in for this useless arm of mine. David plays the 'other hand'.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: The notes first, your interpretation comes on top of them DAVId On top, yes. PARKES enjoys their playing together. He likes DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: You agree, do you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I always agree.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Is that wise? DAVId I don't know. Is it? They play on. DAVID works the pedals; he's wearing odd sh brown one.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Don't forget, it's on the page.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well yes, the notes are, but not the feeling, the emotion

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: You mustn't sacrifice everything to emotion. It's a quest DAVId Is that the question, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Precisely. DAVId I thought so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A throng of students is going up the stairs. DAVID is com bumping into everyone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sorry sorry, oops, beg pardon. You look lovely today, Sar

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thank you, David. david You too, Muriel. Male student Ease up, Helfgott. Laughter; DAVID's popular with them.

dialogues.speaker: REGISTRAR
dialogues.text: Mr. Helfgott. Your allowance cheque. Two students - ASHLEY and ROBERT - look on.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (to ASHLEY) Pay day. David! They flank DAVID as he heads through the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You missed the bank. Pity! You'll have to wait until tomo david Can't bank on the bank. ashley We know someone who'll cash it, David. david Do we Ashley? Do we really? robert What are friends for? As they exit to:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: 'All you need is friends', whoahhh. It's what the Beatles

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: 'Love' dear David… David Yes, Ashley darling? robert Taxi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID crosses to ASHLEY and ROBERT with a tray full of dr bums and grinds. They drink at DAVID's expense and puff o DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID walks along stuffing his mouth with choclate and Co sights. A transvestite with bright red-dyed hair and make dorrway - RAY.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Got a cigarette, love? david A cigarette love - love a cigarette. He offers the packet.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I'm Ray.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ray? Ray! Raylene! Whooah, pleased to meet you. I'm David Ridiculous! RAY lights up the cigarette, then puts an arm around DAVI

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You're very friendly, aren't you David? David Friendly? Do you think so? That's very important isn't it ray If you say so, sweetheart. He steers innocent DAVID into an alleyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up: the bobbing face of a pigeon. It coos. DAVID's sees the pigeon and coos back. His face has traces of mak jacket he's now wearing the lurex vest we say o on RAY. New angle. DAVID is curled up under a massive statue of a Nelson's column). Nearby a MAN hoses away bird shit. Wide shot. DAVID shuffles off in the early morning light, square.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. UPPER WINDOW. RCOM
dialogues.text: PARKES and another teacher, GORDON VINEY, 50, sip tea as window onto the street below.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: He has the most fantastic hands. viney Not connected to anything above the sholders. Their POV. David hurrying up some steps in the College grounds. He d

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: He's a little fragile. viney A chopinzee! PARKES isn't amused.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: I've seen enough to suggest he can make the finals of the

dialogues.speaker: VINEY
dialogues.text: And what have you seen, Cecil? A gleam in PARKES' eye.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Moments of genius. Viney (laugh, bemused) Genius. Oh really! POV below - DAVID scrambles chaotically after his music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID hurries down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: David! He spins around to be met by GILLIAN walking towards him present. ADULT DAVID looks completely baffled.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT DAVID
dialogues.text: Gillian, what are you doing here? INT. DIRECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY - Present RONALD IRWIN - the Director of the College - is a disting He pours tea for GILLIAN while DAVID looks at framed phot certificates on the wall, shuffling from one frame to ano

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Is he aware of what happened? Does he remember? gillian Ask him.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Do you remember much from your student days, David? david Oh yes, yes absolutely. Everything. Well kind of, kind of blank, a bit of a scrabble, the pieces missing - is that gillian You're the only one that knows that. david That's right darling, the only one - gillian You were here. david I was, I was here, that's right I was; it seems to be tru that just the way it is? Gillian The way what is, David? david Scrabble, darling. (To Irwin.) It's a tough game, isn't it? A bloodsport. gillian Not quite. He mumbles on as he turns back to the photos. Gillian Filling in the blanks is what it's all about, as you can IRWIN takes in the mumbling, stooping figure of DAVID, fi believe.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: That performance he gave for the concerto finals, Rachman never forget it; I doubt anyone could. David Whooaahh Professor! It's a photo of PARKES - now Sir Cecil Parkes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors burst open and YOUNG DAVID tears down the corridor. past. He slides to a stop in front of a notice: 'CONCERTO (Patron: H.M. The Queen Mother)'. 'David Helfgott' is on the list of six pinned on the noti

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: How on earth did we manage to make the finals, dear David DAVID - out of breath - can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: You're a conductor's nightmare. DAVID pulls a 'nightmare' face as he registers his name o DAVId It's true, it's true.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? david We're going to win, Ashley-Robert. We're going to win!

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: Are you sure? He takes the Rachmaninov Concerto score from DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm never sure about anything, Mr. Parkes.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: The Rach' 3? It's monumental.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A mountain! The hardest piece you could everest play. A moment. PARKES dares to even consider it.

dialogues.speaker: PARKES
dialogues.text: No one's ever been mad enough to attempt the Rach' 3. DAvid Am I mad enough Professor? Am I? INT. RCOM CORRIDOR. DAY - The present STUDENTS mill past ADULT DAVID, GILLIAN and the College D opposite direction. DAVID's voice 'The point is, I didn't come to London to enjoy myself, g INT. RCOM. SAME CORRIDOR. DAY - The past STUDENTS clear a path for YOUNG DAVID, bumping past them, DAVID's voice 'Got to practice, Katherine; there's three important thin "Work, work, work"…' DAVID hurries from one door to the next, looking into the are all occupied by students practicing on the pianos… ro DAVID's voice 'You see, I am to play in a very special competition and ath the Albert Hall before her Highest Royalness the Quee He arrives at a practice room door, the glass obscured by the inside. He opens the door and is back by the sight of embrace.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whooahh, a duet! Sorry. He shuts the door, sits in the corridor and proceeds to p

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. PIANO STORE
dialogues.text: David's voice 'So I bought a piano, how's that Katherine? …' DAVID presses his face against the window, looking in at grand and concert pianos.
